title: Comparative Biochemistry and Physiology, Part B
abstract: Oysters are considered hyper-accumulators of Cu, but the molecular mechanism by which they maintain Cu cell homeostasis is still unclear. ATP-binding cassette protein subfamily B member 1 (ABCB1, P-glycoprotein) can transport a variety of substrates across the cell membrane in aquatic animals. In this study, to provide insight into the roles of ABCB1 in resistance against Cu in oysters, complete cDNA of abcb1 gene in Crassostrea angulata was cloned and analyzed. The complete sequence of C. angulata ABCB1 showed high identity to ABCB1 from other bivalves and contained some classical motifs of ABCB transport proteins. Abcb1 was mainly expressed in the apical epithelial cell of gills and epithelia of mantles. Abcb1 expression and Cu accumulation were also studied in control oysters and oysters exposed to Cu (30, 100, 300 μg/L Cu, 1-15 days Q4). Cu accumulation in the gill and mantle were measured after abcb1 gene interference. The complete sequence of C. angulata ABCB1 showed high identity to ABCB1 from other bivalves and contained some classical motifs of ABCB transport proteins. The mRNA transcript of abcb1 showed hypersensitivity to Cu exposure. A concentration-dependent highest abcb1 mRNA level (up to 5.61-fold to the control) in the gill and mantle existed across all Cu exposure concentrations after 3 days of Cu exposure. The gill and mantle Cu concentration were significantly higher after the abcb1 mRNA interference. According to these results, it is here speculated that ABCB1 may underlie cell protection against Cu in C. angulata.

abstract.text: Oysters are considered hyper-accumulators of Cu, but the molecular mechanism by which they maintain Cu cell homeostasis is still unclear. ATP-binding cassette protein subfamily B member 1 (ABCB1, P-glycoprotein) can transport a variety of substrates across the cell membrane in aquatic animals. In this study, to provide insight into the roles of ABCB1 in resistance against Cu in oysters, complete cDNA of abcb1 gene in Crassostrea angulata was cloned and analyzed. The complete sequence of C. angulata ABCB1 showed high identity to ABCB1 from other bivalves and contained some classical motifs of ABCB transport proteins. Abcb1 was mainly expressed in the apical epithelial cell of gills and epithelia of mantles. Abcb1 expression and Cu accumulation were also studied in control oysters and oysters exposed to Cu (30, 100, 300 μg/L Cu, 1-15 days Q4). Cu accumulation in the gill and mantle were measured after abcb1 gene interference. The complete sequence of C. angulata ABCB1 showed high identity to ABCB1 from other bivalves and contained some classical motifs of ABCB transport proteins. The mRNA transcript of abcb1 showed hypersensitivity to Cu exposure. A concentration-dependent highest abcb1 mRNA level (up to 5.61-fold to the control) in the gill and mantle existed across all Cu exposure concentrations after 3 days of Cu exposure. The gill and mantle Cu concentration were significantly higher after the abcb1 mRNA interference. According to these results, it is here speculated that ABCB1 may underlie cell protection against Cu in C. angulata.

body_text.text: U N C O R R E C T E D P R O O F
1Q2 Abcb1 gene expression pattern and function of copper detoxification in Fujian oyster, Crassostrea angulata 3Q3 Bo Shi a,b , Xu Xiang c , Yizhou Ke a,b , Long Zhou a,b , Caihuan Ke a,b,d, ⁎

Metal pollution has become a major environmental threat in China because of the extensive use of metals (fertilizers, materials, and metal tools) in agricultural, chemical, and industrial processes. Estuarine and coastal waters are always subject to serious pollution because they are often the sites of major economic development (Pan and Wang, 2011) . One of the classic contaminated estuaries is that of Restronguet

Creek in southwest Cornwall, United Kingdom, which contains extraordinarily high metals (primarily As, Cu, and Zn) concentrations (Bryan and Langston, 1992) . Another example is the Jiulong River estuary in Fujian Province, China, which shows high metal concentrations (Cu, 223 mg/g; Ni, 88 .6 mg/g; and Zn, 1110 mg/g) in the sediments (Wang et al., 2011) . Cu has been toxic in these estuary environments for it is high intake. When present in excess, it can induce redox reactions that generate reactive oxygen species (ROS). These free radicals can inflict direct damage to a wide range of molecules, including proteins, lipids, and DNA (Digiulio et al., 1989; Kayali and Tarhan, 2003) .

Because oysters are filter feeders, they are continuously exposed to environmental pollutants. They are considered as the hyperaccumulators of various heavy metals, especially Cu, zinc (Zn), and cadmium (Cd).

They can accumulate dissolved copper directly by uptake through body surfaces (waterborne), while particulate metal forms can be accumulated by ingestion of contaminated food (dietborne) (Wang and Fisher, 1999) . The most contaminated oysters can have a Cu body concentration as high as 14,000 μg/g dry body weight, and their tissue color becomes blue or green (Wang et al., 2011) . An oyster's ability to accumulate Cu is much greater than that of most other organisms (Han and Hung, 1990; Wang et al., 2011) . To survive with such high Cu concentration in their bodies, oysters have to tightly control intracellular levels of Cu. They may have developed several, probably coexisting, metal resistance mechanisms. Most of the investigations of adaptive mechanisms in oysters exposed to Cu have focused on the subcellular distribution of Cu and its ecotoxicological significance. Partitioning and sequestration are critical to the survival of the oysters with high body concentrations of Cu (Blanchard et al., 2009; Wang et al., 2011; Pan and Wang, 2012) . With the availability of an increasing array of genomic and proteomic tools, many possibly functional genes and proteins have been discovered (Thompson et al., 2012; Garcia-Lagunas et al., 2013; Luo et al., 2014) . It is expected that we may soon understand Comparative Biochemistry and Physiology, Part B xxx (2015)

cite_spans.text: Comparative Biochemistry and Physiology, Part B xxx (2015)

body_text.text: xxx-xxx U N C O R R E C T E D P R O O F

the molecular homeostasis regulation mechanism and how it maintains Cu cell homeostasis. In this study, the Fujian oyster C. angulata was selected as the research object because it is the most important cultivated oyster species and is common throughout coastal areas in Fujian, China.
Their living environment is facing great challenges from heavy metals.

One important group of genes which is potentially concerned with cellular defense is the code for ATP-binding cassette (ABC) proteins. Several members of the ABC subfamily B, especially ABCB1 (P-glycoprotein), can eliminate multiple toxicants from the cell through ATP-dependent processes, either directly following a toxicant's entry into the cell, or following the stages of toxicant metabolism. This protective mechanism is referred to as multixenobiotic resistance (MXR) (Endicott and Ling, 1989; Dean et al., 2001; Hackenberger et al., 2012) .

The MXR mechanism has been shown to be the first line of defense against the environmental toxicants in several aquatic species; it works by reducing intracellular accumulation and limits any potentially toxic effects (Kurelec, 1992; Epel, 1998) . The expression levels of these genes, activity of putative MXR pumps, protein levels, and homology of cDNA sequences of ABC transporter genes have been investigated in a variety of marine invertebrates including worms, sponges, mollusks, daphnia, copepods, sea urchins, and coral (Minier et al., 1993; Bard, 2000; Venn et al., 2009; Della Torre et al., 2012; Cole et al., 2013; Campos et al., 2014; Jeong et al., 2014) . These studies involved many toxicants containing heavy metals (Zn, Cu, Cd), oil dispersants, hydrocarbons, and marine antifouling paints. There are some studies that have focused on the oysters: expression of ABCB1 proteins in the gills of oyster C. virginica and C. gigas; cDNA sequences and expression pattern of abcb1 in C. ariakensis and C. virginica (Minier et al., 1993; Keppler and Ringwood, 2001; Ivanina and Sokolova, 2008; Xu et al., 2014) . Although previous studies have indicated that the MXR mechanism involves many toxicants, water temperature, and specific classes of sediment contaminants, no research has been performed on MXR in the regulation of oyster Cu homeostasis.

In this study, the complete cDNA sequence of C. angulata abcb1 gene was cloned and analyzed. The expression levels of abcb1 and accumulation of Cu in gills and mantles of C. angulata were detected after Cu exposure. Correlations between the gene expression level and dose of Cu toxicity were observed. This was done in order to establish the relationship between abcb1 expression pattern and Cu toxicity stress. The abcb1 gene situ hybridization and interference experiments were performed to provide insight into the roles that the abcb1 gene might play in Cu detoxification and maintenance of intracellular homeostasis in oysters.

All experimental oysters, C. angulata, were collected from the Yunxiao Oyster Culture Zone in China. The oysters ranged in body weight from 8.0 to 13.0 g and in shell length from 45 to 58 mm. Before exposure, oysters were kept in tanks containing natural seawater and allowed to acclimate for 7 days. The seawater used in exposure experiments was filtered through sand and a 0.45 μm filter (salinity: 28‰-30‰; 26°C-28°C). The seawater was changed daily, and the oysters were fed commercial clean algal paste of Chlorella at a rate of approximately 2% of their soft tissue dry weight per day. After the acclimation, oysters were randomly divided into four groups of sixty specimens. Each group was subjected to exposure conditions
body_text.section: Oysters, Cu exposure, and measurement of Cu levels in tissue

body_text.text: ; six specimens were kept as controls (T-0 h). A stock solution of 10 mg/L Cu (CuCl 2 ; Sigma Chemical Co., U.S.) was prepared with Milli-Q-filtered water. The exposed solutions were collected at the beginning and end of the experiment. The samples were diluted with 2% analytical grade nitric acid and then the actual metal concentrations were analyzed by inductively coupled plasmamass spectrometry (ICP-MS). Results showed that the actual Cu concentrations in the exposure experiment were within 87%-93% of the nominal concentrations. The exposure was conducted in 80 L tanks. Oysters were exposed to 30, 100, and 300 μg/L Cu, and controls were exposed to natural seawater. Each group of six individuals was randomly sampled 1, 3, 5, and 15 days after exposure. According to the previous study and our preliminary experiment, gills and mantles are the major tissues that accumulate Cu (Luo et al., 2014) . On the other hand, Cu exposure of aqueous phase was used in this experiment. Gills and mantles were chosen as analysis targets because they made direct contactwith the water environment and absorbed Cu. The gills and mantles were 150 excised from fresh samples and washed in ice-cold saline. Each kind of tissue from one oyster was divided into two aliquots and used for measurements of Cu concentration and RNA extraction, respectively.
The tissues used for RNA extraction were rapidly frozen in liquid nitrogen and stored at −80°C.

The gills and mantles prepared for Cu analysis were dried at 80°C for 36 h to determine the dry weight. They were then digested with nitric acid (70%, Sigma) at room temperature for 12 h and heated to 80°C were sequenced in both directions.
The entire nucleotide sequence was analyzed using the BLAST pro-
U N C O R R E C T E D P R O O F 204

were predicted using the TMHMM Server (http://www.cbs.dtu.dk/ 205 services/MHMM). The prosites (http://prosite.expasy.org/ and http:// 206 smart.embl-heidelberg.de/) were used to analyze the protein motifs.

Molecular weight and isoelectric point were predicted by Compute pI/ using in situ hybridization with DIG antisense RNA probe. Antisenseand sense-digoxigenin-labeled cRNA probes were synthesized using a DIG-RNA labeling kit (Roche Diagnostics, Germany). The fragments of abcb1 were amplified by PCR and cloned. The ligation mixture was transformed into competent cells of DH5α, which was followed by sequencing. Plasmids were used as the template to amplify the abcb1 cDNA in vitro transcription. The primers used are listed in Supplementary File 2. The probes were synthesized by transcribing with T7 RNA polymerase and digoxigenin-11-UTP (Roche) using 1 μg linearized plasmid. The gill and mantle tissues of oysters were fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde buffered with 1× phosphate saline (PBS: 0.8% NaCl, 0.02% KCl, 0.02 M Na 2 HPO 4 , pH 7.4) at 4°C overnight. Paraffin-embedded tissue samples were sliced on a microtome. Parts of paraffin sections were prepared for subsequent staining according to the hematoxylin-eosin protocol to illustrate the structure of the gill and mantle (Fischer et al., 2008) . Other sections were mounted on glass slides coated with 1% poly-L-lysine solution, deparaffinized through two washes of xylene, and hydrated through an ethanol gradient. Then they were used for in situ hybridization according to Yang's protocol (Yang et al., 2013) .
Images were taken with a digital camera (Olympus DP71) on a fluorescence light microscope (Olympus BX51).

During the second phase of this investigation, quantitative real-time PCR (qRT-PCR) was used to quantify changes in abcb1 temporal expression after exposure to three different concentrations of Cu in the gills and mantles. Abcb1-RT-F and abcb1-RT-R (Supplementary File 3) were designed using the Primer Premier 5.0 based on the abcb1 238 coding region. According to a previous study, beta-actin (GenBank accession no. FJ669295) and elongation factor 1α gene (EF1α, GenBank accession no. BQ426516) were used as normalizers (Venn et al., 2009; Cong et al., 2012; Ni et al., 2013) . All the primer pairs were tested to ensure amplification of single discrete bands with no primer-dimers.
body_text.section: abcb1 temporal expression in gills and mantles after Cu exposure

body_text.text: PCR efficiency (E) was determined for each primer pair by performing standard curves from serial dilutions to ensure that E ranged from 95% to 100% (R2 N 0.99). mRNA from each group of six individuals in each stage was reverse-transcribed. The first-strand cDNA was synthesized using a PrimeScript™ RT reagent Kit (TaKaRa, Dalian, China). qRT-PCR was performed according to the manufacturer's specifications (Thermo DyNAmo Flash SYBR Green qPCR Kit, Thermo Scientific, U.S.) on the ABI 250 7500 Fast Real-time PCR System (Applied Biosystems ® , U.S.). Reactions

were made in a 20 μL volume containing cDNA generated from 1 μg of 252 original RNA template, 250 nM each of specific forward and reverse primers, 10 μL of Master Mix and supplementary pure water. The PCR program was as follows: 95°C for 10 min, followed by 45 cycles of 95°C for 20 s, 54°C for 20 s, and 72°C for 20 s. Melting curve analysis of amplification products was performed at the end of each PCR reaction to confirm that only one PCR product had been amplified and detected. Each sample was run in triplicate along with the internal control gene. The comparative threshold cycle (Ct) method was used to analyze the relative expression level, and fold change for the gene expression relative to the control was determined using the 2 −△△Ct method 262 (Bustin et al., 2009) . The average Ct of the beta-actin and EF1α was 263 used to normalize the expression level of abcb1. The data represent the means of four to six replicates, respectively. Comparisons among the different specimens were made by one-way analysis of variance. Significant differences were accepted at P b 0.05.

Based on the full sequence of abcb1 gene from C. gigas, the partial cDNA fragments of abcb1 from C. angulata were cloned and resequenced. PCR fragments were sub-cloned into pMD19T-abcb1 and pMD19T-abcb3 vectors (Takara) and sequenced. pMD19T-EGFP was constructed using a 289 bp EGFP gene (GenBank accession no. EU716633) fragment from a pEGFP-N1 plasmid. All dsRNA synthesis assays were performed as previously described (Priya et al., 2010) . All the recombinant plasmids were confirmed by DNA sequencing. Then, the linearized plasmids were used to transcribe the single-stranded RNA using T7 RNA polymerases (Roche). After incubation at 37°C for h, 70°C for 10 min, and 65°C for 15 min, the DNA template was degraded by the addition of DNase I (Thermo). At last, 1 μL of RNase inhibitor was added to each of synthetic dsRNA in case it was degraded. Finally, the dsRNA was monitored with 1.5% agarose gel electrophoresis and NanoDrop ND-2000 (A260/A280, Thermo).
body_text.section: Cu enrichment analysis after interference of abcb1 gene in oyster gills and mantles

body_text.text: For RNAi experiments, acclimation and daily administration were the same as previously described. After acclimation, the oysters were exposure to the 10 μg/L Cu until the end of the experiment to make sure that the oysters had time to accumulate Cu. After 7 days of acclimation, 6 oysters were randomly chosen and dissected. Their gills and mantles were used for analysis to determine the initial baseline Cu concentrations. Then, 30 oysters were randomly divided into two groups (GFP control group, abcb1-dsRNA). All the dsRNA were injected into the adductor muscle every three days for a total of four times. The shells of these oysters were drilled near the adductor muscle using a microbit (1-2 mm) to facilitate dsRNA injection. The injection volume was 50 μL of saline solution and the dsRNA dose was 100 μg. Approximately 48 h after the first injection, 5 individuals that had been randomly selected from each group were dissected. Their gills and mantles were used for qRT-PCR analysis to determine the effect of the injected dsRNA. The qRT-PCR protocol was the same as that described previously and EF1α and β-actin were used as normalizers. Six individuals were randomly selected from each group, dissected, and used for Cu analysis at the end. The primers used in the experiment were designed using Primer Premier 5.0 and are presented in Supplementary File 4.
body_text.section: Cu enrichment analysis after interference of abcb1 gene in oyster gills and mantles

body_text.text: The full-length transcript of abcb1 gene was obtained by RACE from (Fig. 1) . The sequence contained two typical ABC transporter transmembrane domains, one with six transmembrane helices and the other with four. It also contained two ATP binding sites, which contained typical ABC transporter motifs: the Walker A, Walker B, and ABC signatures and D-loops.
body_text.section: Sequence and phylogenetic analysis of abcb1

body_text.text: A phylogenetic tree based on multiple alignments (Clustal X) of various ABCB transporter sequences from vertebrates and invertebrates was constructed and used to examine the relationships among abcb1s of various species using MEGA 5.0 (Fig. 2) . The NCBI BLAST results
body_text.section: Sequence and phylogenetic analysis of abcb1

showed that C. angulata ABCB1 shared more than 50% amino acid identity with the ABCB1 of Mytilus galloprovincialis (62%), and Homo sapiens (56%). It has the highest identity (67%) and 93% query cover rate with molluscan ABCBs and was more similar to the C. gigas ABCB than to

used to determine the distribution of abcb1 gene expression in the gill and mantle. In C. angulata, the strongest abcb1 gene positive signals were detected in the apical compartment of cells lining the surface of 337 the gills and in the epithelium of the mantle (Fig. 3) . Fig. 4A and B, the Cu enrichment level in the gills began to increase 345 after Cu exposure. The Cu concentrations in the gills of oysters exposed to 30 and 100 μg/L were 1.45-and 2.52-fold that of the control at 15 days
body_text.section: Spatial and cellular distributions of abcb1 expression

body_text.text: . The mantle concentrations were 1.50-and 2.73-fold that of the control. This showed a dose-and time-dependent pattern, increasing with both. At 1 day, the group exposed to 300 μg/L showed the highest gill/mantle Cu accumulation levels among the four groups, and levels began to fall at 3 days. At 15 days, the gill and mantle concentrations were 1.48-and 1.31-fold those of the control but lower than the 100 μg/L group. The cumulate mortality rate was similar to the control (5%) in the 30 and 100 μg/L groups, but reached 20% in the 300 μg/L group, which was much higher than the control (Fig. 4C) .

The temporal expression of abcb1 mRNA in gills and mantles after Cu exposure is shown in Fig. 5A and B. In the 30 μg/L Cu exposed group, the mRNA transcript of abcb1 in the oyster gills increased from 1 day and peaked at 3 day (2.53-fold control levels, P b 0.01) and then decreased to nearly control levels by 15 days. The other groups showed similar patterns that became more pronounced as the dose increased. The highest expression values in the groups exposed to 100 and 300 μg/L were 3.56-and 5.61-fold control levels, detected at 3 days (P b 0.01).

But the expressions of 100 and 300 μg/L exposed groups were not decreased to the control level with continuous exposure, instead, it remained at a high level at 15 days, especially the 300 μg/L group (4.85-fold, P b 0.01). The temporal expression of abcb1 mRNA in the mantle was similar to that observed in the gills and the overall expressions were lower than in the gills. Fig. 6A , the transcript abundance in dsabcb1injected oyster gills and mantles was significantly lower (37%-65%) than that observed in control-injected oysters. The control batch Fig. 2 . Phylogenetic tree of the ABCB1 amino acid sequence between C. angulata and other species based on multiple alignments (ClustalW). Tree was generated using the neighbor-joining method. Relative concordance shown at the nodes is based on 1,000 bootstrap iterations. ABCB1 transporters were submitted to the GenBank database and their GenBank accession numbers were as follows: Chlorocebus aethiops, AAX18881; Homo sapiens, AAA59575; Canis lupus familiaris, ACM77791; Ovis aries, CAM33439; Cricetulus sp., AAA37005; Mus musculus, AAA39514; Gallus gallus, NP_990225; Xenopus laevis, 1098061; Oncorhynchus mykiss, AAW56424; Oreochromis niloticus, BAM36701; Crassostrea gigas, EKC35579; Mytilus galloprovincialis, CAX46411; Mytilus californianus, ABS83556; Crassostrea ariakensis, AET34454; Perna viridis, AFV15804; Drosophila melanogaster, AAA28679; Tigriopus japonicas, AFS49708; Caligus rogercresseyi, AHC54388; Lepeophtheirus salmonis, ADT63773; Populus trichocarpa, ERP64946; Arabidopsis thaliana, CAA43646; Onchocerca volvulus, AAD49436; Saccharomyces cerevisiae S288c, P12866; Trypanosoma cruzi, CAA89197.
N C O R R E C T E D P R O O F

showed more Cu in the gills and mantles than had been present before 380 injection (0 days column) ( Fig. 6B and C) . This showed that the experi-381 mental oysters were indeed accumulating Cu. After a series of four dsabcb1 injections, the Cu concentration in the gills and mantles were both significantly increased ( Fig. 6B and C) .

Oysters have been shown to exhibit a strong tolerance to Cu exposure. It is here hypothesized that they may use a molecular detoxifica-387 tion systemthat may involve the ABC transporter superfamily. ABCB1 388 has been detected in a number of aquatic organisms, and may work by actively transporting a variety of xenobiotics across the cell membrane (Bard, 2000) . Although the transporting activity and expression level of abcb1 in response to metals has been studied in several marine animals (Achard et al., 2004; Ivanina and Sokolova, 2008; Venn et al., 2009; Zucchi et al., 2010; Jeong et al., 2014) , no study has specifically evaluated the role of ABCBs in Cu efflux or resistance to Cu exposure 395 in C. angulate

. In order to provide more information on ABCB1 in bivalves, especially their role in metal transposition, full-length cDNA of ABCB1 from C. angulata were identified and cloned. ABC transporters are constituted of at least two conserved regions, a highly conserved ATP binding cassette (ABC) and a less conserved transmembrane domain (TMD) (Holland et al., 2003) . The C. angulata ABCB1 contains two typical ABC transporter transmembrane domains and two ATP binding sites. This is consistent with the typical structure of other organism's ABCB transporters, such as C. ariakensis (Ambudkar et al., 2006; Luckenbach and Epel, 2008; Xu et al., 2014) . The oyster ABCB1 diverged early during the evolution of eukaryotes, and its genes have continuously evolved. The ABCB1 proteins have strongly evolutionarily conserved regions, found in lower multiple-cell animals and higher vertebrate animals. Among different species of mammals, the ABCB1 proteins show more than 90% amino acid identity (human, Chlorocebus aethiops, Canis lupus familiaris). Unlike the mammals, the ABCB1 between the marine bivalves show major differences outside of the conservative region. For example, C. angulata ABCB1 shared 67% identity with C. gigas and 62% with Mytilus galloprovincialis. Even the C. angulata amino acids show closer to the vertebrates in some regions

. Given the ABCB1 function, this may be in order to adapt to the complex ocean environments. . abcb1 mRNA expression analysis in (A) gills and (B) mantles after three Cu concentration exposures using real-time quantitative PCR. Each bar represents the mean ± SD of five specimens, β-actin and EF1 were used as the reference genes. Differences were considered statistically significant (*) at P b 0.05 and very significant (**) at P b 0.01.
U N C O R R E C T E D P R O O F

The expression distributions of abcb1 were further characterized in oyster gills and mantles (Fig. 3) . Abcb1 was detected in the apical epithelial cells of gills and epithelia of mantles. In previous works, ABCB1 was found on the apical border of a variety of secretory epithelia, such as kidney proximal tubules, gastrointestinal tracts, and biliary hepatocytes of several mammalian tissues (Sarkadi et al., 2006; Lee et al., 2011) . Immuno-localization of ABC multidrug transporters in Indian rock oyster also showed an apical epithelial localization of multidrug resistance protein 1 (MDR1) in the gills, digestive tracts, and cytoplasmic areas of basal cells of the mantle (Kingtong et al., 2007) . Gills and mantles are the oysters' filter-feeding tissues and they take part in respiration and secretion. They come into direct contact with the external environments and are well supplied with blood vessels, suggesting that they are the major barriers between the environments, hemolymph, and internal organs. They are also the primary tissues in oysters that take in metal contaminants (Jing et al., 2006; Luo et al., 2014) . The abcb1 gene showed considerable expression in the epithelia of gills and 434 mantles, which indicates that ABC multidrug transporters also play an 435 important role in the establishment of important biological barriers that help the organism resist environmental stress.

The current study examined the expression of abcb1 after exposure to Cu in the gills and mantles using q-PCR. The Cu concentration of the C. angulata tissues that had been exposed to Cu was then evaluated to determine the expression pattern and Cu accumulation after exposure.

Here, 300 μg/L Cu was found to be lethal to the tested oysters, with 20% mortality recorded after 15 days of exposure, while both 30 and 100 μg/L Cu exposure produced no significant difference in mortality 444 from the control group. In a previous study, C. angulata that had been exposed to 200 μg/L or more of Cu showed disorganization and apical alterations in the cilia cells, hyperplasia, lamellar fusion, and lamellar loss in the gills; hemocytic infiltration in the underlying connective tissue, and numerous brown cells not observed in control specimens (de la Rua et al., 2005) . This suggested that exposure to Cu at concentrations approaching the 300 μg/L disrupted cellular Cu homeostasis and caused severe damage. In this study, the Cu concentration in the gills and mantles increased in a concentration-and time-dependent manner at lower concentrations of Cu (30 and 100 μg/L). The tissue Cu burden of the high-exposure group (300 μg/L) was lower than in the moderateexposure group (100 μg/L). These findings were similar to the frequency of micronuclei in the hemocytes of the M. galloprovincialis after 4 days of Cu exposure: levels were significantly higher at 100 μg/L and a little higher at 500 μg/L (Brooks et al., 2015) . When cells and tissues were severely damaged by high Cu exposure level, less Cu was bioaccumulated.

The abcb1 mRNA expression pattern observed during the exposure phase of this study was concentration-and time-dependent. Previous studies on aquatic animals have showed that the mRNA and protein expression of ABCs increased after exposure to various metals: in reef coral exposed to Cu, in copepods exposed to Cu and Cd, and in Antarctic fish and C. virginica exposed to Cd (Ivanina and Sokolova, 2008; Venn et al., 2009; Zucchi et al., 2010; Della Torre et al., 2012; Jeong et al., 2014) . This indicated that ABC efflux proteins may transport metals or their glutathione conjugates in in vitro mammalian systems and aquatic animals (Leslie et al., 2001; Huynh-Delerme et al., 2005 ). The present study showed similar results during the first stage of the Cu exposure experiment. At day 3, the highest concentration-dependent increase in gill and mantle abcb1 mRNA was observed across all Cu exposure concentrations
. The transcript of abcb1 showed hypersensitivity to Cu exposure in C. angulata.

Significant differences were detected in the expression patterns of abcb1 among low and high Cu exposure condition at day 15. This might be related to an adaptive response that may be mediated by various mechanisms. Cu toxicity was reduced by compartmentalization, such as in the membrane-limited vesicles in oysters (Wang et al., 2011; Luo et al., 2014) . Many factors may be involved in the detoxification for the exceeded Cu. Even to transport the exceeded toxins out of the cell via a membrane protein which includes not only the ABCBs but also other ABC subfamilies. The activity and expression of an ABCC/MRPtype transporter was detected in the gills of the California mussel M. californianus and in PLHC-1 fish cell line (Luckenbach and Epel, 2008; Della Torre et al., 2012) . ABCB1 is only one of numerous possible mechanisms. So when exposed to the low concentrations of Cu (30 μg/L), oysters quickly adapted to the challenge, and many adaptation mechanisms maintain cellular Cu homeostasis. Abcb1 mRNA levels first rose and then fell to nearly control levels at lower Cu levels. A similar observation was reported in the digestive glands of mussels and PLHC-1 fish cell line after long-term exposure to Hg 2+ : long-term exposure does not involve prolonged gene up-regulation (Franzellitti and Fabbri, 2006; Della Torre et al., 2012) . However, as the concentration increases, the expression of abcb1 still remained high in groups exposed to high concentrations of Cu at day 15 (100 and 300 μg/L). The test oysters suffered extreme damage and some of them died (Fig. 4) .

These results suggest that cellular Cu homeostasis was broken when the environmental Cu exceeded a certain threshold. Abcb1 was continuously expressed to transport Cu out of the cell, especially in surviving oysters exposed to high concentrations of Cu.
It is here speculated that Cu was one of the ABCB1 substrates. ABCB1 transporters were found to pump out Cu and play an important role in Cu detoxification.

Previous studies have shown that ABCBs can be up-regulated by compounds that induce cellular damage without actually being ABCB substrates (Chaudhary and Roninson, 1993) . To confirm speculation that ABCB1 can transport Cu as a substrate and play an important role in the Cu detoxification, abcb1 gene interference was performed in the present study. The Cu enrichment levels of the gills and mantle were significantly higher after abcb1 gene interference. The transcription level of abcb1 affected the accumulation of Cu in C. angulata. Some studies in invertebrate animals showed ABCB1 to have similar functions in response to metal exposure. For example, the transport activity of the ABCB1 protein indicated by rhodamine fluorescence was triggered by excess metal intake in Tigriopus japonicas. ABCB1's ability to remove metal was tested in Drosophila melanogaster and soil nematodes (Broeks et al., 1996; Callaghan and Denny, 2002; Jeong et al., 2014) .

These results suggested that when ABCB1 is inhibited, copper efflux is also weakened. It is here speculated that Cu is the ABCB1 substrate Fig. 6 . Cu concentration in gills and mantles after abcb1 RNA interference. (A) Efficiency of abcb1 RNA interference in gill and mantle after RNAi treatment. (B) After abcb1 interference, the gills' Cu concentration was significantly higher than in controls. (C) Experimental results in the mantle were similar to those in the gills. Each column represents mean ± SD (six to eight replicates); *P b 0.05; **P b 0.01 (pair-wise t test). after heavy metals exposure. Aquat. Toxicol. 67, 347-357.

FIGREF0.text: for 8-12 h. After digestion, the samples were diluted and measured by ICP-MS. The dilution protocol and operating conditions of ICP-MS were performed using methods described in previous studies (Luo 161 et al., 2014). ICP-MS was calibrated with external standards, as well as 162 appropriate internal standards ( 45 Sc), to correct for instrumental drift 163 and sensitivity changes.

FIGREF1.text: 2.2. RNA extraction and molecular cloning of abcb1 gene sequencesTotal RNA was extracted from 100 mg of gill and mantle tissues separately using Trizol reagent (Gibco BRL, U.S.), quantified usingNanoDrop ND-2000 (Thermo Scientific, Les Ulis, France), and assessed 168 by agarose gel electrophoresis. The RNA were treated with DNase I 169 (Invitrogen) to remove possible contaminating DNA. Then, 1 μg of 170 total RNA from each tissue was used as a template for the reverse transcription reaction with a Prime Script II first-strand cDNA Synthesis Kit 172 (Takara, China). The first-strand cDNA was synthesized and used as the 173 template for further PCR analysis. 174 Based on the conserved sequence of abcb1 gene from Crassostrea gigas (GenBank accession no. XM_011414311), the partial cDNA fragment of abcb1 from C. angulata was cloned and re-sequenced. To obtain the full-length cDNA of abcb1, both 5′ and 3′ rapid amplification of cDNA ends (5′-RACE and 3′-RACE) were conducted with the 5′-Full RACE Kit and 3′-Full RACE Core Set Ver. 2.0 (Takara, Dalian, China) in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions, respectively. Matching oligonucleotide primers were designed using the Primer Premier 5.0 software (PRIMER Biosoft International, Palo Alto, CA, U.S.). The genespecific primers used in the RACEs are listed in Supplementary File 1. Both the 5′-RACE and 3′-RACE products were cloned into pMD19-T Simple Vector (TAKARA, China) and sequenced. To confirm the accuracy of the sequence of abcb1 through the RACE, pairs of gene-specific 187 primers (Supplementary File 1) were used for amplifying abcb1 188 cDNAs with polymerase Ex Taq (Takara). The purified PCR products were cloned into a pMD-19 T vector and transmitted into competent cells of DH5α, then plated on LB-Agar flat and five independent clones191

FIGREF2.text: gram available from the National Center for Biotechnology Information (NCBI, http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/). DNAMAN (DNAMAN Lynnon Biosoft, Santa Clara, CA, U.S.) was used to identify its encoding protein and to establish the multiple alignments of protein. Multiple sequence alignments and determinations of similarity between amino acid sequences of ABC transporters from different organisms were performed with BLAST on NCBI. The molecular phylogenetic analyses of ABC transporter sequences from different organisms were carried out using MEGA version 5.0, and bootstrap value was computed over 1,000 replications. The transmembrane domains and helices of protein sequence

FIGREF3.text: . angulata gill and mantle tissues. The entire sequence of abcb1 contains a 4113 bp open reading frame, a 101 bp 5′-UTR and a 330 bp 3′-UTR (GenBank accession No. KR091958) (Supplementary File 5). The open reading frame (ORF) encodes a putative protein of 1370 amino acids with an estimated MW of 150.282 kDa and isoelectric point of 5.56. The C. angulata ABCB1 sequence showed a close match to ABCB proteins from other organisms under NCBI protein BLAST (BLAST p). The prosites (http://prosite.expasy.org/ and http://smart.embl-heidelberg. de/) were used to analyze the amino acid sequence to determine the structural organization of C. angulate Q6 ABCB1

FIGREF5.text: Alignment of deduced amino acid sequences of ABCB1 from C. angulate Q1 with human, mussel, and drosophila. Their GenBank accession nos. are as follows: human, AAA59575; mussel, ABS83556; Drosophila, AAA28679. Underlined sections represent transmembrane helices. Typical motifs of ABC transporters are detected and shown with labeled box. Increasing of Cu enrichment by interference of abcb1 gene in oyster gills and mantles mulation, we extended the Cu accumulation studies to examine its functions in C. angulata by RNA interference. At 48 h after the first dsRNA injection, the abcb1 transcript abundance was monitored using q-PCR. As shown in

FIGREF6.text: Distribution of abcb1 mRNA expression in the (B, C) gill and (E, F) mantle of C. angulata as indicated by in situ hybridization. The (A) gill and (D) mantle sections stained by hematoxylin-eosin were used as matched groups. (C) and (F) show negative control sections. abcb1 was localized in the apical compartment of cells lining the surface of the (C) gills and the (D) epithelium of the mantle. Bars, 100 μm.

FIGREF8.text: Oysters' tissue Cu concentrations and cumulative mortality after Cu exposure. (A) The gill Cu concentration of four experimental groups exposed to different concentrations of Cu at different points in time. (B) The mantle Cu concentration of four experimental groups. (C) The daily mortality of experimental oysters. Each column shows mean ± SD (six replicates).

FIGREF9.text: Fig. 5. abcb1 mRNA expression analysis in (A) gills and (B) mantles after three Cu concentration exposures using real-time quantitative PCR. Each bar represents the mean ± SD of five specimens, β-actin and EF1 were used as the reference genes. Differences were considered statistically significant (*) at P b 0.05 and very significant (**) at P b 0.01.

FIGREF10.text: mRNA expression patterns were concentrationand time-dependent; gill and mantle Cu accumulation was significantly 529 higher after abcb1 gene interference.
